results.title: Frankston Motor Cycle Park
results.brief_description: Trailbike riding causes damage to the environment and violence and aggravation between riders and local residents. This video was made to give councils, police and motor-cycle clubs some starting points and pointers towards developing their own locally appropriate solution

results.title: Franklin: wild river
results.creator_credit: Wombat Films, Michael Cordell, Stacey Gavrily and Chris Noone
results.brief_description: Documentary which looks at the controversy over the proposed damming of the Franklin and Gordon Rivers in South West Tasmania and argues for the conservation of this wilderness area. Provides a brief history of the region and follows a three week journey down the Franklin River with Dr. Bob Brown, a conservationist who has intimate knowledge of the river.

results.title: Franklin River journey
results.creator_credit: Anne Whitehead, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Bob Connolly
results.brief_description: This film depicts a three week journey down the Franklin River by botanist Antonius Moscal. Portrays his appreciation of the environment and the studies which he carries out. Suitable for Middle Secondary level. Narration by John Bluthal.

results.title: Franklin River blockade
results.creator_credit: Nick Housego, Kath Scholes and Roger Scholes
results.brief_description: Documents the massive non-violent civil disobedience against the building of the Gordon below Franklin Hydro-electric scheme between December 1982 and March 1983. It is the story of the largest peaceful direct action Australia has witnessed. It vividly portrays confrontation in a wilderness under threat a clash of attitudes. Includes interviews with Dick Smith, David Bellamy and Bob Brown.

results.title: Franklin
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Neurones and John Van Bruggen
results.brief_description: Franklin is a young green turtle, who, like most youngsters is having fun growing up and learning important things as he goes. Three episodes show some of his adventures. In “Franklin’s Kite” Franklin learns that throwing out a broken toy is not always the best thing to do. “Franklin is Bossy” teaches Franklin that everyone has to take a turn and in “Finders Keepers for Franklin” he realizes that finding something means that somebody has lost it in the first place and may want it back.

results.title: Frankie Howerd on campus
results.creator_credit: Paul Lewis, LWT, ITV and Ian Hamilton
results.brief_description: Recorded live for television at The Oxford Union Society, Oxford University, this stand-up performance of one of Britain’s most outrageous and favourite comedians, Frankie Howerd, is thoroughly entertaining.

results.title: Frankie and Johnny
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Nick Abdo and Garry Marshall
results.brief_description: This warm romantic comedy stars Michelle Pfeiffer as Frankie, a cynical waitress who is wooed by the gentle Johnny (Al Pacino), a recently released pretty criminal who takes a job as a chef in the restaurant in which Frankie works. Set around the working class neighbourhoods of New York City, the film is an engaging comedy about the fears and difficulties involved in learning to trust another person. Terrence McNally wrote the script which is based on his acclaimed play, “Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune”. One of the great joys of this film are the uniformly excellent performances. The cast includes Kate Nelligan as Frankie’s fellow waitress; Nathan Lane as her generous spirited gay flat-mate; and the under-rated Hector Helizondo as Nick, the owner of the Greek restaurant in which Frankie and Johnny work.

results.title: Frankenstein's Great-aunt Tillie
results.creator_credit: Tillie Productions and Myron J. Gold
results.brief_description: Comical farce about descendants of Frankenstein’s creator returning to the town of Mucklefugger to live at their unclaimed estate. Aunt Tillie helps the wayward women of the town save their home; the Cradle, rebelling also against unscrupulous and incompetent town officials who endeavour to take over their estate. Accompanied by two lusty side-kicks, the film barely holds together with plot, digressing into many directions at times. Be warned, this is a silly movie. Cast includes Donald Pleasance, Yvonne Furneaux, Zsa Zsa Gabor and Miguel Angel Fuentes. WARNING: THE PICTURE JUMPS AT THE BEGINNING AND THERE IS SOME DROPOUT.

results.title: Frankenstein
results.creator_credit: Carl Laemmle, Universal Studios and James Whale
results.brief_description: A landmark in the history of the horror film, “Frankenstein”, based on the gothic novel by Mary Wollestonecraft Shelley, drew heavily on the traditions of German Expressionism to create a stark, shadowy world where the true monsters were more often in human form. Charged with the desire to create life beyond the womb, Dr. Frankenstein (Colin Clive) constructs a man from body parts looted from freshly dug graves. The resulting “monster” (Boris Karloff) is implanted with the stolen brain of a criminal, and jolted to life by a bolt of lightning. Dr. Frankenstein’s triumph soon turns to tragedy when his creation escapes and discovers that he exists in a world which he is not welcome. Pursued by an angry mob, the creature confronts his maker on a cliff top, setting the scene for the dramatic ending atop a burning windmill. Boris Karloff helped to create one of the most recogniseable (and most imitated) cultural icons of the twenty first century with his sensitive portrayal of the creature, and the film was memorable as a whole for its striking production design, and Jack Pierce’s masterful make-up. Initially on release this film featured a prologue, warning the audience of its potential to shock. Some scenes were cut from the original film as they were deemed inappropriate for audience sensibilities of the time, such as the well-known scene where the creature throws the young girl into the lake. This video features the restored version of the film, and also includes a detailed documentary on the making of the film, produced, written and directed by David J. Skal.

results.title: Frankenstein
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Nightmare: the birth of horror”.
In 1816 on the shores of Lake Geneva, 18 year old Mary Shelley (nee Godwin) would awake from a nightmare that provided the inspiration behind one of the classics of modern horror, “Frankenstein” or “The Modern Prometheus” - a tale of science and birthing. The origins of the nightmare were attributed to Mary’s past: the loss of her mother in childbirth, Mary’s own daughter years later, the philosophical writings of her father, new theories on the origins of life and demonstrations of galvanism. Writer, researcher and presenter Professor Christopher Frayling recounts the now legendary incident in which Mary Shelley, along with husband Percy Bysshe Shelley, Lord Byron and three others, sat around a fireside and recounted a tale of terror to horrify one another. The literary influences on Mary’s writing are outlined, as is the journey from the original novel of the birth of a beautiful creature to the fiendish monster he has since become.
